conversation.content:
[very quietly] Okay, um, levels are good, we're rolling... [pause] The mother just started talking about, you know, the last conversation she had with him and I'm—[empathetically] God, the way her voice breaks when she mentions his name. [clearing throat] I mean, technically speaking, right, the lavalier is picking up everything perfectly, but it's like... [trailing off] 

[focused] Twenty-three years doing this job and honestly, you'd think I'd be used to—[shaky voice] but when she said "he always called me on Sundays," I actually had to, er, check my levels weren't peaking from my own breathing. [sniffle] 

The thing is, we're getting it. [warm] Every tremor, every pause where she's, you know, gathering herself—it's all there. [very sincerely] And her daughter just reached over and took her hand and I swear the room just... [long pause]

[whispering] I should probably adjust the—no, actually, it's perfect. [relieved] Sometimes the best thing you can do is literally just let them speak and, um, make sure nothing gets in the way of their story. [emotional] Because this take, I mean, when they hear this back, they'll know—[crying while speaking] they'll know someone was really listening. Really hearing them. [exhale]

That's a wrap on this interview.

subject: Your production sound mixer work capturing the perfect take that makes the grieving family feel heard in the documentary
